summary: Secret Service
title: Secret Service
body:
read it on the AO3 at http://bit.ly/2AX08d8

by Ladeeknight

Modern A/U that pics up during the Bread Riot in Kings Landing. Think of the Kingsguard as kind of the secret service. To be honest, I do not know where I am going with this fic. It is being written for the Ao3 facebook challenge for January of “write how this group makes you feel.” So in this fic I am Sansa, Ao3 is Sandor (a huge awesome thing that I am just starting to get to know, but I’m pretty sure it’s love) and you all (my readers) are the mob. You are unruly and unpredictable, but ultimately my vehicle to salvation. I don’t think this is going to be dark, but I’ve been wrong before. I can promise that there will be fluff and lemons. If that sounds like your kinda thing I hope you’ll join us.

Words: 2024, Chapters: 1/?, Language: English

  • Fandoms: A Song of Ice and Fire - George R. R. Martin, Game of Thrones (TV)
  • Rating: Explicit
  • Warnings: Rape/Non-Con
  • Categories: F/M
  • Characters: Sansa Stark, Sandor Clegane
  • Relationships: Sandor Clegane/Sansa Stark
  • Additional Tags: Body Guard, Bread Riot, Secret Service - Freeform


read it on the AO3 at http://bit.ly/2AX08d8

summary: sansa: *was a political prisoner* *was married off twice due to her claim to the north* *learnt politics from cersei and...
body:
sansa: *was a political prisoner* *was married off twice due to her claim to the north* *learnt politics from cersei and littlefinger* *ran the eyrie in the books* *led the campaign to retake winterfell* *has the loyalty of the lords of the vale* *earned the respect of the northern lords* *appointed lady of winterfell by jon* *true born daughter of ned stark and therefore has a claim to the northern throne* *is half tully and therefore has a claim to the riverlands* *betrothed to harry the heir to the vale in the books* *still has the ability to warg*

sansa fans: *make content based on all of this*

the asoiaf/got fandom:

tags: a song of ice and fire
summary: Rules of the Game Chapter 4 - Queen takes Castle, Check | Nox on Patreon
title: Rules of the Game Chapter 4 - Queen takes Castle, Check | Nox on Patreon
excerpt: Join Nox on Patreon to get access to this post and more benefits.
description:
In the group there are five of these wild children, each are cautious and their eyes are watchful as they take in their surroundings. The tallest of them steps forth, her hands clasped together with something between them.

“Your Graces. We once roamed this country freely and without care. We have no been pushed to the outskirts of these lands, beyond the wall is all we can call home. Your First Men came and they slaughtered us,” Her eyes scan the guards that now have stepped back, swords sheathed. “We chose to defend ourselves by making the White Walkers and we will be forever indebted to you, Daenerys of House Targaryen, for ending the nightmare we made. As payment for this debt, we offer you a gift.”

She steps forward, the guards grip tightens on their swords, but she places the contents of her hand on the table before stepping away again. Daenerys leans over to see the bright red leaf, it shimmers in the light and as she looks closer it shimmers even with no light. A thin glow flows through the leaf’s veins, neverending in its path through the leaf.

Read Chapter 4 of Rules of the Game on Patreon a week before the public for $1 a month.

summary: Honestly I think that for the first time all of the Sansa hate isn’t bothering me. It’s kind of amusing at this point because in...
body: Honestly I think that for the first time all of the Sansa hate isn’t bothering me. It’s kind of amusing at this point because in a few months all of the haters will be so disappointed that she is in fact an important Stark who doesn’t betray her family.

blog.name: tatticstudio55

summary: So, about the Vale...
title: So, about the Vale...
body:
I just very recently came upon the realization that the Vale and the Eyries have often been ruled by women: in Fire and Blood, there’s Sharra Arryn and the “maiden of the Vale”, Jeyne Arryn. In ASOIAF, Lysa Arryn rules the Vale until her death, then we have Sansa, who isn’t lady of the Vale yet, or “officially” (she’d fit the bill for maiden of the Vale in books/seasons 3-4, however, being a married virgin and having her apartments in the Maiden’s Tower and all), but is probably getting there.

If you remember, in Sansa’s (or Alayne) last AFFC chapter, we have her (Sansa) looking up at the Eyries and thinking that the sky cells made the castle look like “honeycombs”:

The sky cells on the lower levels made the castle look something like a honeycomb from below. A honeycomb made of ice, Alayne thought, a castle made of snow. She could hear the wind whistling round the bucket. – Alayne, AFFC

How funny is that? And how does it work in a bees’ nest?

“Bees live in colonies that contain the queen bee, the worker bee and the drone. The worker bee and the queen bee are both female, but only the queen bee can reproduce. All drones are male. Worker bees clean the hive, collecting pollen and nectar to feed the colony and they take care of the offspring. The drone’s only job is to mate with the queen. The queen’s only job is to lay eggs.” (Source in the comments)

Yup. Very matriarchal. Very female-oriented.

The Eyries are commonly associated with the moon, a symbol of feminity: the creamy white marble in the audience’s room, the moonstones worn by Lysa and Sansa, the Moon Door.  

The Bloody Gate: am I stretching it? Perhaps. But a woman’s core during childbirth would very much be a “bloody gate”. Might also add to the idea of the Eyries as a “womb” where people are safe and recluse. (Until the Moon Door open, that is.)

Any ASOIAF expert out there that would like to elaborate? I’m not too familiar with the history of the Arryns or the Eyries, but this all seems very curious.

The queen’s only job is to lay eggs.” (Source in the comments)

Yup. Very matriarchal. Very female-oriented.

The Eyries are commonly associated with the moon, a symbol of feminity: the creamy white marble in the audience’s room, the moonstones worn by Lysa and Sansa, the Moon Door.  

The Bloody Gate: am I stretching it? Perhaps. But a woman’s core during childbirth would very much be a “bloody gate”. Might also add to the idea of the Eyries as a “womb” where people are safe and recluse. (Until the Moon Door open, that is.)

Any ASOIAF expert out there that would like to elaborate? I’m not too familiar with the history of the Arryns or the Eyries, but this all seems very curious.

trail.content_raw:
I just very recently came upon the realization that the Vale and the Eyries have often been ruled by women: in Fire and Blood, there’s Sharra Arryn and the “maiden of the Vale”, Jeyne Arryn. In ASOIAF, Lysa Arryn rules the Vale until her death, then we have Sansa, who isn’t lady of the Vale yet, or “officially” (she’d fit the bill for maiden of the Vale in books/seasons 3-4, however, being a married virgin and having her apartments in the Maiden’s Tower and all), but is probably getting there.

If you remember, in Sansa’s (or Alayne) last AFFC chapter, we have her (Sansa) looking up at the Eyries and thinking that the sky cells made the castle look like “honeycombs”:

The sky cells on the lower levels made the castle look something like a honeycomb from below. A honeycomb made of ice, Alayne thought, a castle made of snow. She could hear the wind whistling round the bucket. – Alayne, AFFC

How funny is that? And how does it work in a bees’ nest?

“Bees live in colonies that contain the queen bee, the worker bee and the drone. The worker bee and the queen bee are both female, but only the queen bee can reproduce. All drones are male. Worker bees clean the hive, collecting pollen and nectar to feed the colony and they take care of the offspring. The drone’s only job is to mate with the queen. The queen’s only job is to lay eggs.” (Source in the comments)

Yup. Very matriarchal. Very female-oriented.

The Eyries are commonly associated with the moon, a symbol of feminity: the creamy white marble in the audience’s room, the moonstones worn by Lysa and Sansa, the Moon Door.  

The Bloody Gate: am I stretching it? Perhaps. But a woman’s core during childbirth would very much be a “bloody gate”. Might also add to the idea of the Eyries as a “womb” where people are safe and recluse. (Until the Moon Door open, that is.)

Any ASOIAF expert out there that would like to elaborate? I’m not too familiar with the history of the Arryns or the Eyries, but this all seems very curious.
